Yes, very helpful. You and the parents can message each other back and forth, you get the early mornings email to apply for jobs ahead of those that don’t have the premium, you get a free motor vehicle record check (in case you can’t afford just the background check alone which is $33), you can look up your stats to see if parents are looking at your own profile or not, you will also appear on the higher search lists of parents, and if you add a debit card on file, have 3 reviews on your profile front the people that you know well, on top of messaging parents within 24hrs, you get their Carepro status. Premium is just $20/mo or $50/6mo. You can get a discount if you email them on Facebook.
Definitely worth it! We spend more on clothes, shoes, phone, food, therefore I don’t fee this small fee will bankrupt you. However, keep in mind that the premium alone doesn’t guarantee you a job. It will depend on your location, education (degrees), certifications(CPR...), years of experiences, what the job entails, how many kids you will be dealing with and their age matter too and if you are familiar with special needed kids or not. Finally, your biography can be huge help on how you make it outstanding or not. Good luck and screen through more posts on this topic!

No. They go through as much of a check as we do (none) unless you complete a background check.  There is no family background check. I always have a phone interview before meeting. I often search the name on facebook, look up the phone number. These things are not always reliable, but often times the phone number comes up with a matching name or I do find them on facebook. That being said, don't freak out if the number comes up under a different name, as I recently changed phone numbers and know someone else comes up under mine. I would use those more as a possible bonus comfort check than a definite red flag raiser. Some red flags I would note are if the number comes up as a texting app number or something strange. When it comes to in person interviews, you can ask for a public first meeting at Starbucks or something. If they want you to come to the house and you're comfortable with it after a phone interview, I always let my boyfriend know where I'll be, when I'll be there, and if I don't text him within an hour to just give me a call and check in.

I’ve been wondering this because I’ve had some very questionable & some really negative experiences that I feel other nannies should know about. Story time: I had a situation where I was working with a 1 year old who’s mother seemed like she was trying a little too hard to be my friend. I went along with it but I discovered that she had a really bad attitude. a situation arose where the baby got sick and she asked me to not come that next day. I was thankful that she wanted to take care of him herself because I prefer not to care for sick children, to prevent getting other children I take care of sick. She called me and while we were talking I asked what the baby had. She got a terrible attitude with me saying how it wasn’t my business and a lot of other things, I politely explained that I didn't mean any harm but I would like to know if he might still be contagious whenever she asked me to come back. Well, she went off. I never argue with stupid. As soon as I felt my blood begin to boil listening to her rant, I hung up. I calmed down and composed myself then I called back to tell her that it wasn’t going to work out, we just weren’t a good fit but she didn’t answer. So i texted it. surely I wasnt going to show up to a confrontational, argumentative and hot tempered persons home after that and expect her to be civil with me. She retaliated by writing a negative review. A Totally false review by the way 🙄 has anyone else had any experiences like this? Am I the only one who feels we should be able to leave THEM reviews also?!?! They want reviews, references, and a background check for us but I’ve been in some situations where I felt like I wish I had more information on the parents. They are strangers to us as much as we are to them. I’m sure it’ll never happen, just a little pondering that I thought i’d share.

Okay, Sheryl :) I have some answers for yoooouuuuu. Your biggest issue is that you are not vetted in any way shape or form. People are hiring a stranger offline so they need something to be able to trust that they as parents are making the right decision. You may have woooonderful experience, but they have no evidence from your profile and that's the only thing they are going to see at first. And actually your bio doesn't describe any previous childcare experience. There is just no evidence to say how in the world you would be with other folks children.

Number one:
Reviews and "cared for" number up

Number 2:
Background check

Number 3:
Bio needs to sell any childcare experience you have

Number 4:
Change your profile pictures please-1st one should be "professional" headshot with just you, 2nd one-aaaawwwww cute doggy! :) But he is sadly irrelevant to this profile, particularly the way he is in the center of that picture. 

Number 5:
Your profile says full-time, but as you've stated you are looking for part-time so you need to change that, or else the folks looking for part-time help will have a hard time finding you. In addition your calendar is completely filled out so it DOES look like you are looking for full-time so definitely if you can fix that asap. :)

Now that I am done with the things that are a work in progress:

Great job at filling out your calendar! :) Excellent for being CPR and First Aid Certified. 10+ years experience? Fantastic! Now I just need some evidence of what you did in those 10+ years to be reflected in your reviews and bio.

So we have some baby steps to conquer here. If you could start working on some of those things. Then feel free to come back to me if you'd like and I'd be ever so happy to see what the next steps should be. If you need help developing a more fleshed out bio, all I would need to know is what are some actual things that you have done in childcare and we can get cranking on a fantastic bio for you. :)

Hope that helps! Feel free to let me know if you have any further questions, Sheryl :)

My response...

This is literally a slap in the face. You guys ought to be ashamed of yourselves. This is a money scheme and nothing more. Because I can guarantee that NO Caregiver on the site asked to have a required $15 fee to KEEP their account. If you guys were ACTUALLY listening to your Caregivers, the ones who bring you more account holders, you would read TONS of stuff on the site, community forum, that everyone is appalled by this FORCED fee. They ask us for references because they’re looking to hire us. So we provide them. If we ask to speak to a former nanny of theirs, it’s likely they will get insulted because we are checking them out just the same. To make sure they are “normal”. I feel since we aren’t hiring them, they’re not going to like the request very much. They don’t want us to have the inside scoop on their behaviors. I know if a new nanny asked me about my former employer, I’d tell the truth and it’s likely the nanny wouldn’t take the job. I don’t think they want former nanny’s telling a potential new nanny their business. When they interview me, I am going to be taking care of their children. They deserve references, a criminal background check and DMV check. I interview them as I’m there. I decide if they seem like people I want to work for. Sometimes it’s a pass. That’s the only reference I can base it on. Gut feeling. I’m not paying them to do anything for me so asking for a reference may insult most employers. Just my opinion. I wouldn’t do it.

I have had several full time job offers from parents on this site. I am currently working full time for a very nice family. Care is very straightforward about the fact that they are merely allowing people to connect. However, whenever I have complained about the behavior of a parent, they have revoked that person’s membership. At the same time, they are like any business, they need to make money. They can’t have us all on here for free. I have never paid for a background check on myself. I encourage the parents I interview with to do a background check on whomever they choose to hire. Yes, some of the people on here are dodgy, but everyone is an adult. If Care vetted everyone who posts an ad or published a nanny profile, they might as well shut the site down. You can answer all the ads you want, but some families are so picky, they will pass people over for silly reasons. I once interviewed with a family that had 38 responses to their ad. That is a lot of nannies to choose from! I think we probably outnumber the potential employers on this site. I have also seen nannies say they charge so much per child, etc. I don’t know where these nannies supposedly making $60,000+ live, but it certainly isn’t upstate NY.

To answer your question about the background check, yes, you need a social security number to get a background check. It’s how they confirm they are checking the right person. I’ve gone through many background checks for various jobs/internships and they always ask for a social security number. The background check companies use secure sites so that your information is safe. I’m extremely cautious about sharing really personal information, and will only do it on secure sites or in person. Never email a social security number. 
You don’t pay monthly for background checks. You can pay monthly for a premium membership, but that is not required. I’ll throw out there that I got a really good job without a premium membership. You can choose to pay for your own background and motor vehicle check, but that is also not required. I would put in my applications that I was willing to undergo any checks they wished. That way it showed I was serious and willing, but then they paid for it. 
As far as being nervous of paying things online, the only advice I can give you there is to religiously monitor your bank accounts. If something doesn’t seem right, contact your bank. I pay all of my bills online and honestly trust it way more than pay by mail. You can be smart about it. 
Good luck and I hope this helps!

I keep communication wide open. I send pictures and videos throughout the day of their little one. I also explain my goal for the day and how I plan to run the days activities. Talk about age appropriate activities or stages you've recently read about (it's good for parents to see you still care even off the clock) 

I agree with the person who commented before me about the background check, exchanging license info and them speaking to your references. Also talk about your CRP qualifications and any medical training you have, parents need to know you're prepared and capable. Even if you already know, ask the parents for a refresher on their med kid and where all emergency info is. (They'll feel better knowing you want to be and stay prepared) 

All of this helps with establishing trust, but the best advice anyone can give you is to simply keep communication open and frequent. 

Good luck! 

-Ash

To start a Family Day Care, 
First, you need to be certified by the city or town you plan to have a Family Day Care.  It is 12 weeks class.  You may also include to take the class that is offered by the DSS.  I think DSS has a new name now.   There are children who you may babysit that came from a dysfunctional family and you need to be certified by the DSS also.   But you do not that certification right away.  The most important is that you call the city Hall that you would want to open a Family Day Care at your home.  To start a Day Care for the first time, there are very important things for you to know in order to get approved and certified by the city or town where you are conducting a Family Day Care.  After you received all the papaerworks and filled them up it takes 12 weeks to get it approved.   The city assigned someone to go to your home and check everything inside your house.   They do a criminal background check on you and everyone who live in your house.   Drinking and smoking are not allowed while the kids are in your care.   Also, they check the condition of the house and second floor is not allowed.  Only first floor is allowed to conduct a Family Day Care.  If you live on the first floor and the building has other floors and there are people who live their that has criminal background the city will not approve your application.  If everything is okay with them between the house  condition and also must have a backyard for the kids to play because they only allow 6 children including your own child or children.  It takes 12 weeks to get the approval by the city.   You also have to call the IRS to get EIN number if you plan to hire someone to help you.  If not because you are self employed you may use your Social Security for now until at the end of the year you pay what is due to the government.  After everything is dais and done then  you start advertise to every parent that you are conducting a Family Day Care.  I think I covered everything.

So with this site if you can afford it I suggest you become a premium member! It’s possible to get a job without it, but I personally like premium for a few reasons. Hi Karen,

The argument that families are at the mercy of their nannies is one-sided because nannies are equally at the mercy of their employers. There are numerous cases (nationally and globally) of nannies being abused by their employers... this includes physical abuse, financial abuse (e.g. withholding or skimming pay) and so on. It just happens that the reverse i.e. cases of nannies abusing children gets more media attention. 

Next, if googling a parent's name should be sufficient for nannies, shouldn't that be sufficient for families as well? Of course not. Walking into a strangers home is not easy, the same goes for letting a stranger into your home. Both carries risks. However, families have an advantage here since they typically obtain a wealth of information from and about their caregivers prior to hiring them. For example, references, SSN, criminal background check, motor vehicle check, reviews and (or) letters of recommendation, etc. Caregivers don't have that. So, I don't see what's so dramatic about a nanny asking for that little in return. Families are not the only ones with concerns for their privacy, wellbeing and safety- nannies need and deserve the same.

 If we are to compare what Victoria wrote to working in a company, I would say that those who work in companies and similar capacities have more information at their fingertips than nannies/caregivers. First, it's more likely than not that one can find information about a company on various outlets- Glassdoor, Social Media/Network, LinkedIn,  Google and so on. Thus, making it easier to find or even talk to former and (or) current employees of a company without asking the employer. Secondly, some companies facilitate correspondence between prospective employees and those in their alumni network. Childcare professionals namely those that work in private households don't have that privilege. 

As for where are "young people are getting this idea of asking for references from"- that's assuming it's only young people who ask for that- I reckon it has to do with the fact that the industry and society at large is ever evolving. Think about it, there were things nannies, teachers, parents and co could do back then that they can't do today e.g. being allowed to spank a child. It was a norm then but a crime today. So, although this idea might seem shocking to some people today, it could very well be the norm tomorrow 😊

Best,

Remember, you want to be sure that you are a good fit with the family, not just that they think you’re OK. If there seems to be something about their home or lifestyle that you know is going to make you very uncomfortable, tell them you don’t think it will be a good fit if they do want to hire you. 

Examples: If you’re a “clean freak” and there’s a dirty cat box in the living room and cats eating and lounging on the kitchen counters, you’ll probably end up unhappy. If you’re into Wicca or nature worship, seeing indications that they are devout Christians or Jews, may end up causing you uneasiness or difficulties in the relationship. 

Long term Nanny jobs are almost like marrying in to a family if you’ll be working in their home and taking children to events the parents arranged and approved of.

 I immediately found a job that lasted three and a half years, until my client had to go into a Nursing Home because she needed 24-hour care and her daughter decided that was the best way to handle it.

I'm on CARE CHAT and it's totally FREE. 
How it works is, after you sign up for it, employers/ families that have a paid membership can CONTACT YOU ANONYMOUSLY through this site, and then you can respond to them ANONYMOUSLY.  (and I THINK that if YOU are a paid member, and the clients are NOT, that YOU can CONTACT THEM-- because WHOEVER is the PAID member, has to INITIATE  THE COMMUNICATION).  

Also, when you sign up on Care Chat, you will have to choose a SPECIFIC Symbol so that you will know when you are being notified through the Care Chat option. 
Then you can choose to CALL them, or text them, but EITHER  WAY, it is done ANONYMOUSLY (& the phone # option will be a long distance #, but you will ALWAYS see the symbol you chose to CONFIRM that it is ANONYMOUS).

BUT, if THEY have a paid membership, THEY can contact YOU, WITHOUT going through the ANONYMOUS/Care Chat option, so BE CAREFUL!!!!

And in the past, when people have CONTACTED ME to OFFER me a job position, and they have INCLUDED THEIR personal  email, or THEIR personal phone number (NOT thru the Care Chat option),  Care.com will IMMEDIATELY send me a text and tell me that they RECOMMEND that I do NOT respond to them through any kind of PERSONAL CONTACTS until after I've had a chance to communicate with them ANONYMOUSLY thru CARE CHAT, and THEN once I am CONFIDENT that they are SAFE, and ONLY THEN should you arrange an initial meeting in a PUBLIC PLACE (for SAFETY REASONS). 
And that's because your IDENTITY is PROTECTED THROUGH THIS SITE, but once you give them any PERSONAL info, you are VULNERABLE, especially to SCAMMERS!!!

....And just to let you know, if you DO PAY for a membership, I recommend that you NOT pay for MORE than ONE month AT A TIME. Because, if you find a job within that paid membership, and you try to put your membership on HOLD, they will NOT do it, and you will still be charged IN FULL for what you've already paid for.

I have a few suggestions that work for me. 

1) when applying for a job, do NOT use a canned response that you save over and over for every application. Personalize your letter to include details they mention in their ad. Demonstrate that you took the time to read and pay attention and you are genuinely interested.

3) pay for the DMV check, the background check, and contact your local fire department about CPR class and pay for that too (usually about $50).

4) Make sure you mention that not only do you have s positive review from your current family, but that they are willing to talk to new families on the phone. I’m very lucky— my current employer has talked to many potential new employers for me. It’s made a huge difference.

4) post several photos of yourself, including one of you with kids you’ve worked with (get employer’s permission) and make a video.

5) last but definitely not least, write a profile/bio that talks about what you live about being a nanny and what you are passionate about. Don’t just make a list of your skills.

Thank you for sharing. I think reviews and background checks are always great ways to get families attention. I would also share a little bit about how you got started in childcare and what makes you passionate about it.

Employees & Employers vary so much, in so many ways! What might be an issue for one, isn't for another. An example I can give is while interviewing with a couple of a newborn (their first) they asked if I would be ok with cameras in the common areas & baby's room. I responded, " I do not LIKE being on camera or being watched. But this is your CHILD, you have every right to feel safe while leaving her in my care so yes I would be fine with that". I also advised them (as a Mother as well), "If someone does not agree to it there may be a reason why & you may want to consider that a red flag". So many variables! I am not even going into the horror stories of employees stealing or abusing the children, or where Employers have abused or put the Employee in dangerous situations. But to end, I do believe there can be a happy medium if you are prepared & ready to state what is acceptable & what isn't for you.

The good thing is you can just screenshot the background check and when the “timing” expires in 90 days and you’re asked to get a new one, you’ll have it saved. Also, when families really want the background check and you send them the out of date one (which they typically don’t notice)... They will then upgrade their own acct in order to get your updated background check or whomever the other contenders are. Once you that happens, you’ve scored, because you now have access and can take pics of your new background check. It also will up your rating by HUGE because when a family req your check you get to view it, it shows on your acct you have a background check, & you can send it out to potential clients! Definitely place a pic of yourself on your profile, as well. So many new people looking for a nanny, see a baby pic and assume you are either looking for a nanny, as they are, have something to hide, or will be bringing your child with you while watching theirs. Building off what everyone else has said, I have some additional tips to elaborate on and increase your odds based on my past experience.

1. Profile Bio —check spelling, grammar, presentation, and flow as you highlight experience, certifications, past experience(s), special skills, volunteering in the community, and overall make yourself stand out.  This is one of the first things families see when evaluating compatibility to their needs.  Your bio is a business profile so make it look like one.

2. References/Reviews —having feedback on your profile makes a huge difference; if you’ve done any childcare for friends, neighbors etc. in any capacity, see if they’d be willing to submit feedback on your account.

3. Background check —this is another scale tipper; having this shows you are serious about services you provide.
4. Letter of introduction/application —Like your profile, check spelling, grammar, presentation and flow as you submit applications and even more important is acknowledging details from job posting.  For example, if a job posting needs someone willing to undertake certain responsibilities or certain days and times, say something like, “I see you need someone Monday-Thursday 8am-3pm.” Highlighting/mentioning specific details shows you read the job posting.

5. Keep persisting.  There’s no telling how many applications you’ll have to send before you get a bite but it will pay off.  With enough effort,  you can find a good fit.

Use the promo code CARESAVE for 20% off (I think?). I pay for 1 month at a time because if I get a job in that first month, I cancel my premium subscription. It does remove my background check, which is annoying, but I print it off to have in case my current family requests it.

2. Make your application peppy and personal. Families want to see that you're excited to work with them. I start with "Hello!", add the phrase "Here is a little bit more about me" before diving into my credentials, and close it out with "Your family sounds awesome and I would love the chance to work with you, even if it's just as a date night sitter!" and always, always thank them for their time!

3. Take an extra 5 minutes to personalize your application. Do they want someone with a car? If you have one say so! Do they want someone who can also tutor in math and you've helped kids with math before? Mention it! Half the time people are only looking at your application and not your profile, so list things like CPR training, skills, and whether or not you have a car. I have a base application saved and I add things specific to each application.

4. Mention things other than childcare! They are bringing you into their family and want to know you! Talk about your hobbies. I mention that I like hiking, crafting, and science. It makes a huge difference and you seem like a more well-rounded person

I hope this helps!

Hey there,

I've noticed that there a LOT of jobs I can't apply for. I paid for the full background check and for a month of membership. Any tips?

Hey Kayla!
I'll be extremely honest; as you're new, and with Covid such a gamechanger, it's not going to be easy =(

Even for parents who ARE actively seeking nannies during this Pandemic, because of so many child caregivers being let go and fewer jobs being posted, in many areas, it's even more competitive than pre Covid. Parents may get 30-60+ applicants applying to their one job and most of the time you may be 'seen' but never get a reply either way, especially if they find someone they like. 

Please ALSO be looking for jobs beyond here; don't just use this as your main job seeking platform and hope for the best. 

Anyways, with all that being said, a few tips (which you can also check in the 'popular topics' section on here)....

-Make sure your profile bio has minimum grammar and spelling errors. Do NOT say anything about needing to work asap/needing money/saying you are a good Christian/Muslim/whatever woman, etc. 
Add info like how much experience you have, your available schedule, any certifications, etc. 
Do NOT copy/paste your Profile bio to each message you send. Looks lazy. Send each parent a personal message. 

-Having a background check on file helps

-Reviews help. If you have prior paid child care experience, a few reviews from those parents definitely helps. There's a link you can send through the Care site. I know many say that if you don't have child care reviews, use character reviews from friends/teachers/professors, etc but ultimately it's the child care ones that really look good (imo.)

-For your safety, do NOT give access to your BGC, any references or a resume to any parent until after a thorough phone interview in which both parties feel comfortable going forward at minimum AND at their request. I never volunteer my BGC or references to parents unless asked. 

-Check the going rates in your area so you are not charging too low but also not putting yourself up so high that's not the norm for where you are. 

Hope this helps and wish you well!

The profile page is basically a personalized resume. You want to make it sound friendly, but informative. Tell them about what makes you a good caregiver. Tell them about experience and even hobbies and educational things that are relevant to making you a good caregiver.
It’s best to do the actual applications fairly individually, tailoring them to the specific family. For instance, if they have young children, I tell them crafts and outing things I like to do with little ones. If they want someone who will be comfortable with dogs, I tell them about growing up with big dogs and having done rescue. These individual things are things you should be looking for to know if a family is suited to you so you don’t waste time applying to jobs that really aren’t going to be a good fit. Read between the lines and consider all the info they give you. For instance if they say the want coverage from 6 am-12 am (midnight) M-F, but have it listed as part time, they may want to tie up your time all week, but only have you work (and get paid) for 15 hours a week. Or they may just think 12 am is Noon and need just mornings. You can ask in your app to clarify what the job “really” entails so you don’t bother going through background checks, etc., then find out the job won’t work for you.

![Home Care Service](https://image.freepik.com/free-photo/closeup-support-hands_53876-14962.jpg "In-Home Care")

In-home care can significantly improve the wellbeing and quality of life for seniors. They reduce the need for hospitalization and allow aging seniors to recover from an illness or injury in a familiar environment. Thus, professional in-home care is an ideal choice if your senior parent or elderly loved one needs more help living independently that they did before.

However, choosing an ideal in-home care service can be a rollercoaster ride, especially with the sea of options available today. Knowing what qualities to look for in such home-care service providers can help you make a suitable decision, allowing your senior to live a comfortable and independent life.

##**1. Strong Reputation in the Senior Care Domain**##

The first quality that sets an in-home senior care provider from the others is their reputation in the domain. Reputable and experienced in-home care agencies will be talked about by their clients. They carry excellent client reviews and positive comments on their company website, social media channels, and Google reviews.

Further, established in-home care services are transparent about their licenses, certifications, accreditations, care plans, and the costs. Make sure you gather the following information to gauge the agency’s trustworthiness and expertise in senior care.

*   How long have they been in the senior care segment? Who’s the founder? Go through their company history and read about them on Google.

*   The licenses, accreditations, and awards they have received

*   The senior care plan they offer

*   What type of training do they conduct for their staff?

*   Contact information of a few of their clients

You don’t want to compromise on offering the best care for your aging loved one. Use this information to determine whether or not you are dealing with a reputed and trustworthy senior care agency.

##**2. A Skilled Team of Professionals**##

Before selecting an in-home care service, it’s important to interview their team and assess their expertise in senior care. An ideal in-home care service provider will proudly talk about their team and be open to organize an interview session for you.

Check whether the team of caregivers, aides, therapists, and nurses are qualified and experienced in elderly care. For instance, they should be able to help seniors with the [activities of daily living (ADL)](https://www.care.com/c/stories/15077/activities-of-daily-living/) like bathing and dressing and offer nursing care for an illness or a disability. Further, they should be experienced enough to recognize the mood and behavior of the aging senior and know how to manage them. They should also be able to handle their medical supplies with ease.

Consider asking these questions to make an informed decision in this matter.

*   What are the types of professionals do they have? Very few agencies have a strong team of registered nurses, physical therapists, memory care specialists, speech therapists, occupational therapists, nutritionists, and home health aides.

*   How experienced is the staff? How long have they been with the agency and in the senior care field?

*   Are they trained in senior care? How equipped they are to deal with emergencies? Do they possess the required certifications like CPR and first aid certifications?

*   What kind of background check has been done before hiring the staff?

*   Who supervises the in-home care professionals?

*   Does the same care professional attend to multiple clients? OR Do they offer dedicated staff?

*   What happens if the care provider doesn’t show up?

*   What’s the insurance cover like? Will you be protected against thefts or loss of property due to accidents?

Besides, ask for work and personal references to access their trustworthiness, punctuality, and ability to handle stress and emergency situations.

##**3. Customized Senior Care Plan**##

Seniors have a variety of needs. Some may require medical aid while others may just need assistance with their daily activities. The in-home care service provider you choose should be able to customize their care plans according to the needs of your senior.

Ideally, in-home care service providers should offer the following types of home care for the elderly.

**Private-Duty Skilled Nursing Care**

This includes a skilled nurse who’s trained and experienced in providing care for seniors with diseases and disabilities, monitoring the vital health signs, administering medications, and using devices like the ventilator, catheter, and feeding tube. If your senior needs long-term nursing care, this is the in-home service you should opt for.

**Home Health Aides**

These are non-medical care professionals who help seniors with ADL, meal preparation, and other household tasks, allowing them to live an independent and safe life. They offer companionship to seniors and engage them in hobbies and recreational activities. This service is ideal for seniors looking for assistive care and companionship (not medical care).

**Home Health Care**

This includes short-term physician-prescribed care to cater to a specific illness or injury. The visiting nurse, clinician, or health care aide is an expert in offering physical therapy, occupational therapy, and other services until the senior recovers.

Before making a decision, check all the services offered by the in-home care service provider and choose the one that best caters to your needs.

##**4. Quick Emergency Response Services**##

How adept is the care provider to the change in your need? A senior’s needs can change suddenly. At one moment they may need assistive care while on another day they may require a skilled nurse to care for a sudden illness or accident. The service provider you choose should be able to quickly adjust to these changes.  

Finally, does the service provider have backup care in case your in-home nurse or caregiver doesn’t turn up? They should be well-resourced to offer a skilled professional who can effortlessly fill a shift or two. Further, not all home care service providers are available 24/7. So, it’s critical to check whether they are contactable round-the-clock to cater to emergencies. 

##**Wrapping Up**##

In-home care is the most suitable option for seniors who desire to live a comfortable, safe, and independent life in their homes. However, not all in-home care service providers can be trusted to offer the same level of senior care. Therefore, it’s important to research well before opting for one.

Consider the information shared in this post to offer the best quality care for your senior loved one in their aging years.

I have been using care.com on and off for 3 years now and here are my suggestions:

1. If you can, pay for premium. It's kinda necessary for messaging, it boosts your stats, and you get a vehicle background check included in the price. Use the promo code CARESAVE for 20% off (I think?). I pay for 1 month at a time because if I get a job in that first month, I cancel my premium subscription. It does remove my background check, which is annoying, but I print it off to have in case my current family requests it.

2. Make your application peppy and personal. Families want to see that you're excited to work with them. I start with "Hello!", add the phrase "Here is a little bit more about me" before diving into my credentials, and close it out with "Your family sounds awesome and I would love the chance to work with you, even if it's just as a date night sitter!" and always, always thank them for their time!

3. Take an extra 5 minutes to personalize your application. Do they want someone with a car? If you have one say so! Do they want someone who can also tutor in math and you've helped kids with math before? Mention it! Half the time people are only looking at your application and not your profile, so list things like CPR training, skills, and whether or not you have a car. I have a base application saved and I add things specific to each application.

4. Mention things other than childcare! They are bringing you into their family and want to know you! Talk about your hobbies. I mention that I like hiking, crafting, and science. It makes a huge difference and you seem like a more well-rounded person

I hope this helps! Just have a little patience too!

Hi Lisa! Make sure you have a profile photo. A nice, professional-looking head shot; you don't need to pay for a professional photo, but it should look professional, if that makes sense. Make sure your applications are tailored to each job posting so that families know that you are actually interested in working for them and have made the effort. I write mine like cover letters. Also, excellent grammar and punctuation are imperative in applying for jobs. If you are not a strong writer, I recommend asking someone who is to proofread for you. The background check for your profile is a good start but what else have you done? Are you CPR & First Aid certified? That's a must for caregivers. You'll be alone with their children and they will want to be assured that you will know what to do in case of an emergency. Do you have any reviews yet? You can receive reviews from people you haven't worked for through care. There is a link you can send to anyone who is willing to provide you a review (coworkers, past employers, volunteer connections, friends/family, teachers, etc.). Fill out a bio that has your education, experience, and certifications. Also put why you want to be a caregiver/nanny/babysitter/pet-sitter. Talk about your passion and things you love to do with them. List your characteristics that you make you an ideal caregiver (patient, active, crafty, baker/cook, loving, nurturing, etc.). 
Lastly, try be patient. This is not an instant job site and can take a while for many to find a job. It's going to depend on the type of job you are looking for, your location, and you as a candidate with how competitive you are. You want to take your time to find the perfect family and not settle for something because you are desperate. Listen to those instincts. Care doesn't have the same safety net as an agency does, so if things go wrong, you're kind of on your own. 
Good luck, Lisa! I hope you stick around here and keep us updated (:

I copied and pasted this from another post that I responded to a few days ago......

I’m sorry but every time I see a post along these lines, it amazes.....astounds.....even somewhat confuses me that those that are new seem to think that if they apply for 20, 30, even 50 jobs......that they will get massive responses. This site does NOT guarantee anyone a job. They are the middle man, the intermediary, the go between.....helping those seeking childcare connect with those who are looking for a childcare position and visa versa. If you are young and have little to no experience, it’s going to be very difficult to find a job. If you are a college student who can only work certain days & certain hours and that changes with each semester, it’s going to be difficult to find a position. Yes, I applaud you for your hard work & dedication in getting your education, but the majority of families are looking for someone full time or part time with set days & hours.
If I’ve said it once, I’ve said it a hundred times.....you can apply to one hundred jobs and beyond that with the exception of a follow up message (thanking the family from accepting your application and that you look forward to hearing from them soon) there is absolutely nothing you can do. A family listing a job may get dozens of responses. They may or may not read all of them. They may skim through and pick just a few. If you are not among the chosen few, do not expect any kind of acknowledgement. In over 2.5 years and the dozens of applicants that I have put out, I have received TWO responses that basically said “thank you for your application, but we have decided to go in a different direction”. One of you must have premium in order for messages to go back & forth. I see so many caregivers say “I’m no paying for premium. I’m not paying for a background check. Those are the responsibility of the employer,” Did you ever stop to think the potential employers are waiting for applications thinking “It’s not my responsibility to get premium or pay for a background check, if they want a job badly enough they will pay for it.” Did anyone ever think of that? And if they want a background background check on every person that they interview, even four interviews add up to over $100. If one is hired, $75 down the drain. If no one is hired $100 gone for nothing. No one seems to want to look at both sides of the coin....job seekers OR potential employers.
You can have what you believe to be the best references, experience and application.....and you can stand on your head and sing Mary had a Little Lamb until pigs fly, but there is absolutely nothing that you can do to make anyone respond to your application, in any way-shape-or form.

TIPS FOR THOSE WHO APPLY AND GET 0 RESPONSES TO APPLICATIONS! 
THERE IS HOPE RIGHT AROUND THE CORNER, MY FELLOW CAREGIVERS! 

I WAS IN YOUR SHOES TOO!
My heart goes out to all the new caregivers who have joined this community seeking help and advice about what to do to get a job on care.com after sending out so many applications, yet continue to receive no responses in return. I was in your shoes too when I first started out, and it is most frustrating. 

IT IS SURE TO CHANGE! READ ON!
But I want you to know that it will change! You can’t give up! care.com is amazing! And I want to help you and tell you what helped me and changed everything so that now the people are actually messaging me with job opportunities that I am able to choose from! I have met the most amazing families on there and have a very full schedule and love my jobs.

I know that other fellow community members have responded to your posts so well with great and wise advice, so you may have already figured out by now how to improve and get jobs.  But I decided to tell my story and how it worked for me and to put my ideas on one post, hoping that others will add their ideas to this post and people who need help can refer to it, instead of them to be all over the place.

MY BACKGROUND:
I have been babysitting since sixth grade and love engaging and playing with all age groups of children. They have always been my greatest joy and I adore them! I have worked with children for years in teaching Sunday school class, and worked for many years as a teacher in a private church school, and as the head leader for many years of a Gems Girls Club (like Girls Scouts) for a church and in our community, among other things. I also am an energetic, seasoned mother of three children. I have been married for 34 years to my supportive husband. He took care of me for many years when I was chronically sick with Lupus and MS. I am much better now! I also love to cook meals for families and clean houses too. 

I also am on care.com as a mother looking for babysitters, so I know what the employers are looking for in a caregiver and who they pass right by! So I have some advice about that as well to share.

MY TIPS:
Now that you know something about my work and personal history, I would like to give you some tips about how I got started and how I finally received job responses! 

POST THAT PHOTO AND VIDEO RIGHT AWAY! A MUST!!
But first, let’s focus on signing up on care.com. First, you should have had no problem filling out general info and verifying your social networks, (If your social networks are not verified, someone who is looking for a babysitter is thinking, what does she not want me to see on her social media? Why is it not verified?), picking out a very clear frontal photo to post and then posting a video. Wait! I notice most people chose not to post a video! But I feel this is very helpful! I use the photo booth video setting on my computer and set it in front of me and click on video and talk away. Then post it. It gives parents an extra feel for your special personality and see a bit of who you really are!! And I don’t understand why people don’t post photos. When I look for a babysitter to hire, do you know that I skip right over you when I do not see a picture! I want to see what you look like before I even ask you to come meet my child! You really need to post a profile picture! Ask a friend to help! 


TWEEK YOUR BIO TILL IT IS CLEAR AND HAS ALL THE IMPORTANT DETAILS BELOW!
Work hard at posting a clear down-to-earth bio about you and your love for children and your work with them growing up or whatever your life bio is. It should include your education, your experience working with children, why you love babysitting or what you like to do when you are taking care of kids (crafts, outdoors, homework help, etc.), and then add a sentence about you to make it personal, maybe about a couple hobbies you have and important character traits, like dependability and patience. (Some of these ideas were from a post I have read previously on care.com. They have so many helpful tips on every subject that you can refer to on their site!!)

RECORD YOUR WORK HISTORY, EVEN INDIVIDUAL NANNY JOBS AND BABYSITTING JOBS, AND ALL JOBS PERTAINING TO CHILDREN OR NOT!
Work History was a hard one for me to put on paper since I have babysat for so many people mostly long ago who have come and gone and I wanted to use the ones I wrote down as references for prospective employers to be able to call. But I came up with plenty, even from highschool days, and I know the people to this day. I didn’t call all of them, but would have if I needed to. I also recorded the other work history mentioned pertaining to working with children and in the comments, I wrote about my unrelated jobs working at a bank, Dr’s office, and dentist’s office for years. 

SAFETY VERIFICATIONS: A MUST-HAVE!
I think this is worth every penny to pay for to have on file. Parents always want this verified before they even consider you as their nanny or sitter. The money you spend for this will pay for itself when you get lots of jobs! They will come!

KEEP YOUR AVAILABILITY CURRENT!
I notice that it is pretty common that not many people keep up with this feature. It is very helpful if you do keep this up-to-date for the parents looking for babysitters! It doesn’t take but a minute!

APPLICATIONS SHOULD BE A FRESH, CREATIVE, PROFESSIONAL MESSAGE FROM YOU EXPLAINING WHY YOU ARE RIGHT FOR THE JOB, INCLUDING THINGS BELOW! 
I highly suggest that you do not send the bio to the employer as your application!!! I get this all the time when I am looking to hire a babysitter. Boring!! Not personal at all! Lazy, in fact! It is annoying to receive the same thing as your bio, when you are asked to write the following:
“Write a professional message explaining why you are right for the job. Mention your skills, work history, certifications, and anything that makes you stand out!” 
But, not many do this! That sentence is written by care.com on the application page! That is what they want you to write about on the application.
I think it is pretty cut and dry and self-explanatory as to what to add to your application. And yes, they will see your bio too. Always proofread it and have someone correct your grammar and spelling. It is so unappealing. 

“FOLLOW-UP” in a couple days to see if they have hired anyone, and re-state why you are a good fit for the job,” care.com suggests in one of their helpful articles on line. “They may have just forgotten you in the shuffle of applications flowing in!”

ALSO, DON’T FORGET TO:

BE AMONG THE FIRST TO APPLY!
BE PERSISTENT!
RESPOND BACK BY THE MESSAGE DEADLINE!
WHEN YOU DO GET A MESSAGE, AND THEY REQUEST AN INTERVIEW, BE ON TIME!!!

SAMPLE APPLICATION:

Good Morning, Kathy R,

I was so excited when I read your job description! I just love working with your child’s age group. I have been working with four to six year-olds for five years now at a kindergarten in my  town. I enjoy engaging the children in play, doing age-appropriate crafts, playing outside activities, teaching them in class, and so much more! 
I finished college with a business degree. I have CPR training, do not smoke, and have my own car.
Children of all ages bring me great joy! I also have experience babysitting for children of all ages for at least 10 years. 
I love to hike, swim, and draw. I would love to meet you and your child. I am dependable and patient and kind-hearted. I believe that I would be a great help to you with my experience. I have plenty of references that you can refer to. I hope to hear from you soon. Thank you for your time! 

Respectfully, 
Suzie Y.

(I am no expert!! This is just my opinion and my attempt to help. Nothing is set in stone! Everyone has their own brilliant and creative way of writing. I just wanted to give a brief idea of what to write.)

REVIEWS:

To me, this was the most important category that finally got the ball rolling and things happening for me on care.com! I think that these reviews are the #1 things parents look for on the the site! They are eager to see what people are saying about an applicant. If there are good reviews that say that their children love their sitter, that the sitter is reliable, and other good things, then they are going to message him/her over above someone with no reviews, for sure!

Some have said how hard it is to get reviews. I thought that too. But I began asking people I babysat for in highschool! I even just asked people I have just been friends with for a long time or family friends who know my character, and who know how much I love children and how well I care for them and what kind of a devoted friend and loving mother I am. These people were thrilled to send a message to care.com. 

There is a link you can send to their email, if you feel funny asking them verbally. The link asks them, and they send the link with their review back to your profile! VERY easy! I even put my profile on my facebook timeline. There is a link that promotes you and your care.com profile. Look for it on your page to do yourself! That may help you to get some babysitting jobs. I even posted it on all the local cities’ support groups and market places and did get a few responses from there. This all gave me a good start. I would ask everybody I could think of for a review! 

Before long, I started to get a handful of reviews dribbling in! I was so grateful, because soon after that, I received a couple messages, and the responses to my applications started to come! I was so excited. Time went on, and the reviews kept coming in, and I applied for more jobs and began to even be messaged by people looking for care! 

But, once in a great while, the cycle stops for a short time. This, to me, means that I need to change things up a bit! Perhaps change my photo and make it more up-to-date! Or, tweek my bio a bit more! Change some wording and add some more creativity. Update my availability, check my work history and make sure I have added any new people that I have recently worked for on care.com too! 

Be sure to always ask the people you work for that have hired you from care.com for a review even after a good month of working for them. I know by then what I think about my new sitter and whether I think she is going to please me and be dependable or not and I know exactly what to say! I love writing reviews for my sitters. It is an honor. So don’t be afraid to ask. On your profile, there is a place for you to just click on their name and request a review! Very simple!

BENEFITS OF PREMIUM!
A question a lot of you had was the question whether to pay for premium so you can be in the Pro care category, which is the top category on care.com. I have to say yes for sure, because if you don’t, you will miss out on the full benefits of the site. Here are the benefits:
Your profile will appear higher than others in the search results; you will be notified of jobs sooner than everyone else; You can see families who have not posted jobs yet; you will have multiple payment options; you can communicate with no conditions attached, etc. etc. You won’t have to do this for too long, only till you get the jobs you need! Sometimes, a lower-paying monthly fee plan is offered out of the blue! So be checking for that on your page.

DON’T GIVE UP!
Most of all, don’t get discouraged! Be encouraged by the ones like me that go before you that started out JUST LIKE YOU!! We had to apply to tons of apps too, my friends, and go through the longgg agonizing days of waitingggg. But to me, it was not that bad at all. It was worth the efforts. And suddenly, it all comes together and yes! One day, it will happen!! You will jump for joy at that first new job, work it, and then get that great review! That review will lead to more and more!! Mark my words. Don’t give up!! Thank you for reading my post and I surely hope even a bit of it has helped in some way.

I didn't have any reviews when first joined and was able to land a full-time nanny position, so don't let that discourage you! Your area may be really competitive. Check the site or your app very often (several times a day) so you can reply to postings quickly. Trying to get a few one-time jobs to get some reviews like Maryanne suggested is a good idea. Definitely don't use your profile bio as an application, but it looks like you've already figured that out. I would even be careful using it as a template. I write my applications like cover letters, so once I created a basic nanny cover letter, I would use that as a template and tailor each one to the specific job posting. Use specific keywords and responsibilities from their job posting. That lets the family know that you actually read the posting and care enough to take the time. 
Your grammar looks great! That's huge and can definitely help you stand out. I see a couple of things you could change, though. I would say First Aid instead of 1st Aid. Also, are you certified in adult or pediatric or both? I would specify that. There also shouldn't be quotations around baby. "A lot of experience" sounds a little more professional than "lots of experience" in my opinion. Do you have an Associate's or technical degree in child development? Definitely be specific if you do have a degree. If not, it still looks good and you can leave it how it is. 
If you have not undergone the background checks and don't wish to pay for them yourself, you can say in your applications that you have a clean record (only if you actually do) and are willing to undergo any background checks. Some of my tips to be safe are:
- apply to jobs that have very detailed job applications or have a profile picture.
- don't share your info such as cell or email until you know for sure they are real (they shouldn't ask for very personal information).
- they agree on a phone interview or face-time.
- they agree to an in-person interview (if you feel uncomfortable meeting them in their home, ask for a public area to meet in).
- if they give you their address to meet in, look it up to see if the place looks sketchy or not. 
- look up their names with their address to make sure they are real people. 

Make sure to always be safe and be cautious with anyone who contacts you. In the end, its up to you to verify the job is safe.

Are your employers withholding taxes from your paycheck? If not, do not give them your SSN. If they are withholding taxes, you will need to fill out a W-4 form and put your SSN on that form. They might want your SSN so they can file for a childcare tax credit. In that case, they will need your SSN. Don't share your SSN unless they are paying you properly and withholding and paying taxes. They should not be able to benefit unless you also benefit. 
Are they asking for your SSN so they can run a background check. If so, they can request a background check through Care and it will be at their expense and they will not see your SSN. 
Ask your employers why they need your SSN. If it's for payroll/tax purposes, then you will just need to show them your card and fill out some paperwork with your personal information. They don't need to make a copy or keep your SSN. 
I hope you understand what I've said and I hope it helps. Good luck and congratulations on your new job.

I have been using care.com on and off for 3 years now and here are my suggestions:

1. If you can pay for premium. It's kinda necessary for messaging, it boosts your stats, and you get a vehicle background check included in the price. Use the promo code CARESAVE for 20% off (I think?). I pay for 1 month at a time because if I get a job in that first month, I cancel my premium subscription. It does remove my background check, which is annoying, but I print it off to have in case my current family requests it.

2. Make your application peppy and personal. Families want to see that you're excited to work with them. I start with "Hello!", add the phrase "Here is a little bit more about me" before diving into my credentials, and close it out with "Your family sounds awesome and I would love the chance to work with you, even if it's just as a date night sitter!" and always, always thank them for their time!

3. Take an extra 5 minutes to personalize your application. Do they want someone with a car? If you have one say so! Do they want someone who can also tutor in math and you've helped kids with math before? Mention it! Half the time people are only looking at your application and not your profile, so list things like CPR training, skills, and whether or not you have a car. I have a base application saved and I add things specific to each application.

4. Mention things other than childcare! They are bringing you into their family and want to know you! Talk about your hobbies. I mention that I like hiking, crafting, and science. It makes a huge difference and you seem like a more well-rounded person

I hope this helps!

I copied and pasted this from another post that I responded to a few days ago......

I’m sorry but every time I see a post along these lines, it amazes.....astounds.....even somewhat confuses me that those that are new seem to think that if they apply for 20, 30, even 50 jobs......that they will get massive responses. This site does NOT guarantee anyone a job. They are the middle man, the intermediary, the go between.....helping those seeking childcare connect with those who are looking for a childcare position and visa versa. If you are young and have little to no experience, it’s going to be very difficult to find a job. If you are a college student who can only work certain days & certain hours and that changes with each semester, it’s going to be difficult to find a position. Yes, I applaud you for your hard work & dedication in getting your education, but the majority of families are looking for someone full time or part time with set days & hours.
If I’ve said it once, I’ve said it a hundred times.....you can apply to one hundred jobs and beyond that with the exception of a follow up message (thanking the family from accepting your application and that you look forward to hearing from them soon) there is absolutely nothing you can do. A family listing a job may get dozens of responses. They may or may not read all of them. They may skim through and pick just a few. Hi Rachel, to answer your questions below-
The CareCheck results are not made public and you cannot share them on your profile. The Criminal+MVR background checks that you or a prospective employer purchases are stored on your profile. A prospective employer can request to view it and you will need to grant them access to it. Also, keep in mind that Trustline background checks are not as thorough as the background checks on Care. Trustline only searches statewide. The company that does the Care background checks search nationwide. Some families prefer a more thorough background check. Every family is different. It's not mandatory for you to purchase an background check. I had a family request a background check and they paid for it, actually the company that the father worked for paid for it. If the family wants it, you can let them incur the expense. The background check will stay on your profile and expire after 6 months. Good luck to you!

Two things:

If neither has a paid account, they will not be able to respond to your application. 2. I kinda have a rule about which jobs I apply to. If the post consists only of the auto-generated sentences, I don't even bother.  I figure I want to work for someone who can take the time to compose at least a few sentences about the care of their child! Similarly, I don't just copy and paste my job applications. I write directly to the specific family. If they mention their toddler is hard to understand, I assure them I speak fluent toddler. If they say they'd like a nanny who goes above and beyond, I explain that Mary Poppins is my spirit animal. I am also specific about my experience. If they have a 2 year old, I tell them how I love to read and sing and make trains out of cardboard boxes. If they need someone to help with homework, I mention the 13-year-old kid with dyslexia and ADHD I've tutored, or the 6 year old whose phonics lessons are usually concealed  in games and art. 
I also list pertinent qualifications or abilities with fun words and tidbits of info to give them an idea of who I am: "I love to cook (homemade calzones, anyone?), I play the piano and psaltery, I thoroughly enjoy swimming, and have my own dependable transportation."
Promote yourself, know your worth, and give details in your application. I don't ever do the background check, but I say that I am totally comfortable with it. Also explain that you will give references after further communication.
I think I have as many pictures as they'll let you add. They aren't professional, but photos that portray a responsible, mature, happy, fun adult - at a 5k, hiking, etc. Good luck!

You should be communicating only through the care text, back and forth, until you establish that this is a job you’re really interested in: the right hours, pay, job duties, etc. Then you do A care chat phone interview. Come on now, think about what you’re saying.... Who in their right mind will hire a pregnant nanny who will need to leave for maternity leave in 90 days, for 90 days. I copied the majority of this when I responded to basically the same question a few days ago. Apparently some thought I was too harsh, truth is I was telling it how it is......still am, just going to soften it up some. 

This site does NOT guarantee anyone a job. They are the middle man, the intermediary, the go between.....helping those seeking childcare connect with those who are looking for a childcare position and visa versa. If you are young and have little to no experience, it’s going to be very difficult to find a job. If you are a college student who can only work certain days & certain hours and that changes with each semester, it’s going to be difficult to find a position. Yes, I applaud you for your hard work & dedication in getting your education, but the majority of families are looking for someone full time or part time with set days & hours.

You can apply to one hundred jobs and beyond applying with the exception of a follow up message (thanking the family for accepting your application and that you look forward to hearing from them soon) there is absolutely nothing you can do. A family listing a job may get dozens of responses. They may or may not read all of them. They may skim through and pick just a few. If you are not among the chosen few, do not expect any kind of acknowledgement. In over 2.5 years and the dozens of applications that I have put out, I have received TWO responses that basically said “thank you for your application, but we have decided to go in a different direction”. One of you must have premium in order for messages to go back & forth. I see so many caregivers say “I’m no paying for premium. I’m not paying for a background check. Those are the responsibility of the employer,” Please look at it from the other side,  stop to think the potential employers are waiting for applications thinking “It’s not my responsibility to get premium or pay for a background check, if they want a job badly enough they will pay for it.”  And if they want a background background check on every person that they interview, even four interviews add up to over $100. If one is hired, $75 down the drain. If no one is hired $100 gone for nothing. No one seems to want to look at both sides of the coin....job seekers OR potential employers.

You can have what you believe to be the best references, experience and application.....and you can stand on your head and sing Mary had a Little Lamb until pigs fly, but there is absolutely nothing that you can do to make anyone respond to your application, in any way-shape-or form.

If you get a response and an interview, then are offered the job....please please do NOT accept the position: if it doesn’t “feel” right, if you get to the interview and suddenly the number of hours & hourly rate are significantly reduced, if the job is just too far (one way or round trip)—you don’t get paid to drive to & from work. If you REALLY REALLY WANT the position, request mileage reimbursement, $0.58 per mile per IRS and get in writing.

Welcome to the community where members can ask questions, answer questions, rant, share stories, and the like with fellow caregivers all over the country.  My name is Sam and I am a classically trained musician in two instruments living in SE Ann Arbor, Michigan.

Finding a good job in any industry is certainly going to be challenging and even more so in one as competitive as childcare.  

I am happy to offer suggestions on steps you can take to improve your chances finding a good fit with a family.
1. Clean Profile—your bio is a business profile so make it look like one as you highlight skills, experience, certifications, education, unique qualities, etc.  Check for proper spelling and grammar as you edit, revise, tweak and rewrite until you are satisfied with end result.
2. Applications —Just like your bio, a well written letter of application is going to be noticed.  In addition to skills and experience, be sure to acknowledge what family is looking for as you mention examples listed in job posting.  There’s no telling how many letters you’ll send before you land a hit so don’t give up.
3. Background Check—Having a background check on file is definitely a scale tipper; it shows families you’re serious about your services.
4. References—These days, it’s not just what you can do or know but also who you know that spells the difference between victory and defeat.
5. Reviews —Having reviews/feedback on your profile also makes a difference; for any child caring you’ve done in any capacity (friends, neighbors, families on care.com, etc.), see if they’ll write a review to help boost your chances of getting noticed.
6. Certifications—are you certified in CPR/First-Aid?
7. Education—Can your field(s) of study be applied in childcare industry (I.e., degree in ECE)?  I for example majored in psychology and minored in music and am able to apply both with children I care for in many creative and imaginative ways.

After getting further consideration from interested family, prepare set of questions to ask your potential employer that are relevant to job that weren’t mentioned in posting.

If you are selected for position, get arrangement in writing to cover all bases and prevent being recipient of short end of stick.  Make sure your contract has guaranteed pay within set/agreed schedule, a cancellation policy, paid vacation, paid sick days, holiday pay, overtime pay if working more than 40 hours (or in some states, more than 8 hours in a day), severance pay, late payment clause, and anything else you think is necessary.  

As a single mother, you have the added challenge of finding a family that is open and accepting to idea of caregiver bringing own children to cut down cost of care so be sure to establish that detail early in the job search process (maybe include in letter of application somehow).  

I’m sure other users will have suggestions I neglected to mention but hopefully this will give you a good jump start.  Good luck.

Hello, i am an older woman that has been on care.com for many years with great success.  I would say the following to 20 year olds and adults.    The only difference is our age and I believe there are alot of people that will give you a chance with the following comments:

Know as a teenager caregiver the reality is you do not have the years of experience.

However, within 2 weeks of showing up 5 minutes early, leaving your cell phone off, bring and 5 x 7 ring note pad and be prepared to take notes regarding  the following:
Ages of children

Names ; write them down it is easy to get nervous and forget. (Adults too). 

Dress appropriately, casual nice clothes.

Remember to not show up preferably chewing a bunch of gum.

Write down nap times

Take a babysitting course for teens. 

 I have found the more certified courses you are taking the better the chance to get that job.

Write down meal times

Write down contact numbers and ask if it is more than one person leaving which person to call first. .

All parents should ask you if you have taken CPR, THAT is a class the red cross (or local fire station) offers for infants and children  as well as adults and seniors. 

Be polite, no loud music! Respect the area you are in.  (AGAIN THE SAME FOR.ADULTS)

No friends over ABSOLUTELY NO!

As I said I am am adult, and it is not an.easy job and I admire you for reaching out to ask.  But, a very rewarding job, and I believe a very good reality for you.  You have been doing this for 5 years so you must like one or two things about it

Common sense is having a background check ready to share

If you will be driving the children, allow me to mention an extremely important ISSUE - THE CORRECT TYPE OF DRIVERS insurance FOR CAREGIVERS.

This is different in every area, and if you are driving with your insurance and your car and are getting paid by your client, remember you can be reimbursed for mileage as well as you will be liable for any thing that happens to the children in a accident. (They are typically  not covered under personal auto insurance, when a client is paying you), but please check with your Car Insurance Agent!

To avoid this, let them know you drive, but if you take their car you wont need the special insursnce.  As a teenager sitter, I realize that your rates vary based on where you live? But quite frankly all of the issues would add up very fast.  It would be rare in my opinion that they would ask you to drive them anywhere but I do not know the specific situation.

Please supply your prospective clients (if you feel it is an good fit.  Meaning they are people you feel will meet your qualifications as well.  It goes both ways. After you have been doing this for 15 plus years, you will realize that there are many clients that you will get along great with! But the reverse is true.  Some personalities just do not match.  This takes time and experience but I feel.you will do a great job.   Do not take those situations seriously.  It is not about you.  Move on with positive attitudes and the ability to provide excellent service to your next clients.

Also, at NSO (nurses service oganization) OR insuranceBee.com they offer very fair priced liability insurance for a part time sitter for 109.00 a year. 
(Liability insurance) which I think of above and beyond for you, but i think clients are asking for this more and more.

I personally don’t spend the money on premium. I understand it has its advantages, but, to me, it’s not right to ask job seekers to pay and give employers the option not to. Any employer not willing to cough up some money for a membership (which is pennies compared to an agency cost), is unlikely going to be paying their nanny or sitter the money they are worth. I think it opens it up to more scammers and predators, too, in my opinion. So, as you may be able to tell, my choices are based on principle. But if I was searching for date-night or petsitting gigs, not full-time nanny jobs, my outlook may be different. Although, on SitterCity, I can find those jobs without paying, since asking caregivers to pay is not something SitterCity does. 🤷🏻‍♀️
Unless you are looking for date-night gigs only, I wouldn’t pay for your own background checks, especially if money is tight. What I did was include in my applications that I was willing to undergo any background or drug tests they require. That lets them know that it’s not that I’m trying to hide anything. Once you get further in the process, like after interviews, if the family is intent on hiring you, they can request the check and that allows them to pay for it, not you. This is for long-term positions. If you’re only doing date-night or petsitting, I would be tempted to pay for one, personally, but only if I was getting some interest. And again, add in your applications that you’re willing to get one. But I was only looking for long-term jobs, so I let the employer pay for them. 
To add in my story, I was able to get a job without paying premium. I was unemployed at the time and had no income coming in. I was trying to save as much money as possible, which included not spending money on frivolous things like clothes and eating out, so it’s not like I was just being cheap and stubborn. I really didn’t feel like I had the money, and I get very anxious about money. To me, this wasn’t a cost I wanted to endure. People feel differently about it, and we are all entitled to our own opinions and views. I just wanted to share mine with you. 
One thing you can do is give it a try without it, but if you’re not having luck within a few months, revisit the option. Especially if you are finding that you are applying to jobs that already have so many applicants, and not getting responses. One thing about premium is getting that early notification so you’re able to be one of the first to apply. That was the feature that appealed to me, but I wanted to give it a try without premium. I told myself I would revisit the option in a couple of months if I was still unemployed. 
I hope this made sense and has helped you! Like I said, we all have different opinions, but it’s good to read a variety of experiences so you can make an informed decision 😊 Good luck!

Hello, it depends on what state you live in.   I am in Washington State, and if you are awake all night, it is anywhere from $15.00 to - $25.00 per hour.  The caregiving Independent Private Caregiving Business is all about the clients needs.  If you are just starting out, I would ask them, what is the rate you are paying for this, but I would not ask that until later down the interview road. 

What I have experienced after 17 years of experience, is that money is the last thing to be talked about. 

In Washington State, with the experience I have in Advanced Alzheimer's, Geriatric Care, Congested Heart failure, as well as numerous post operation experience, I walk in, and get to know them first.   

Always listen to the client and their needs.    There are some people that will try and pay you a very low wage.  You know your experience, you know why you are getting into this business. 

My biggest piece of advice, is to become Certified in many areas of aging. 

There are Certificates of all types, and having those certificates on your resume on Care.com really show a person that is faithfully interested in doing this for reasons other than money.   You need to have a giving heart, and I am sure you do, but there are people that do this job, because there is a shortage of people, and unfortunately this has split the private professional care givers from the Assisted Living and Independent Living Caregivers. 

Remember, we are in a situation, where caregiving is going to be at its highest demand in the next 10-20 years.  

I would become a Certified Elder Care Advocate, as well as a Geriatric Assistant (without the RN), as that allows you credentials that are well respected. 

I know this is way more than you asked for, but like I said, I have a book of knowledge on my 17 years. 

The other last thing I would do is show everyone you have purchased a 50 state Criminal and Felony background check.  There are many that do not.  It leaves no questions that you are clear of these issues. 

Good luck, and do your best.

Unfortunately care.com does not require or even have a way of running background checks on families. I complained about that in an App Store review and they just brushed it off saying their sight was safe. 

It it’s basically all up to you to do your due diligence. My recommendations are:
1. Only apply to families that have a profile picture
2. I don’t give any of my personal information out until after an in-person meeting (that includes releasing my background check for them)
3. Never take an in-person interview without a phone interview first. Not just for safety, lots of people lie/embellish in their posts and then you’ll find out it’s not at all what you were thinking. So don’t waste your time on an in-person interview just to find out it’s not a match
4. I do not EVER for any reason meet with a family in a private setting. If they aren’t cooperative with finding a public place to meet, move on to another family. 
5. Ask for references for the family. You’re going to be in their home, you have the right to verify their aren’t crazy people just as much as they have that right for you. 

I hope this helps you get started. Hopefully Care.com will see the error of their ways soon and have background checks for families as well.
