For me, I find that I need to make sure the family is serious about me before ever meeting up with them.

I find that some families can give you a ‘false hope’ to keep you on a sting so that you don’t apply elsewhere...just so they have you as a backup.

I experienced this with 3 families back-to-back — families hiring me ‘they say’ then not following through. In the meantime, I would have several other families trying to interview me, but I had to decline because I was already on the hook with the family that said they wanted to hire me.

Anyway, this only happened 3 times back to back...and then I learned my lesson.  I use a lot of intuition and pay close attention to the person I am chatting with. If I find any ambiguity or changing of meet-up times, etc...then I find a way out of the interview so I don’t waste time.

I have found the best jobs to be the ones where they found me first. I don’t ever apply anymore. I just make my profile as good & flexible as possibly so that they will seek me out. I asked for reviews, I paid for the criminal background check, I pay the monthly fee so that I am advertised first, I get certified for first aid, CPR & swimming training, child development classes, I mark ‘yes’ on almost every service offered even though I my main focus is to take care of the kids...and not clean the house.

My bio mentions how safety conscious that I am. I say something like “I am happy to adhere to parental guidelines, but I am very safety conscious, so there will be times that I use my own judgment to make sure the child is safe.”  This is actually true about me.

It took time to develop a good reputation so that families would seek me out. I had to be strategic.

Here’s another tip, if a family says that they will pay between $12-18 per hour, what they really mean is that...they won’t pay more than $12 per hour - period! So, I don’t even apply to jobs that mention a pay rate that I cannot do. I don’t like wasting time.

Also, I have come to learn that families like lots of references. When you do get a reference, make sure it is a 5 star. The first 3 references set the ‘tone’ for your desirability.

Anyway, again...just ‘change your game’ and figure out what works best for you. Also, you need to remember...for every job posted, there are about 40-50 applicants. So...be the first to apply. Be excited that they interviewed you - it’s a good sign!

5000 character is actually more than enough space to put everything on your profile. I was able to do mine with 2500 characters (maximum allowance). Everything goes in your profile. 

You will firstly write something like:
CPR/AED/FIRST AID Trained & BACKGROUND CHECKED. PLEASE NOTE that I am NOT COMFORTABLE with BIG DOGS (but ok as long as they are 2 feet away from me). Small dogs are ok. I am ALLERGIC TO SOME PERFUMES/strong scents (please be gentle on it).
Secondly, you add your POLICIES. If you are busy on M-F from 8am to 7pm for example, then write:
 PLEASE CAREFULLY READ MY PROFILE & CHECK MY TENTATIVE CALENDAR FOR MY AVAILABILITIES BEFORE REACHING OUT AS I AM UNAVAILABLE  on MON-FRI from 8am-PM
or you can say ** AVAILABLE ONLY DURING THE WEEKEND. NOT SEEKING FULL TIME OR PART TIME POSITION.
Your Biography shouldn’t be that long because you can write 3 sentences for your education, 3 sentences of who you are and what you do and 3 sentences for what you are willing to do when interacting with kids. Most website will already let you select if you want to work with infant, toddler, or teens so you don’t have to repeat those on your biology neither your age nor your rate or distance you are willing to work from. You have to summarize everything by being brief and precise.

Karen, have you asked the family why they need your SSN?  Do they need it because they plan on claiming a childcare credit on their taxes? If so, they need to have their accountant or  a payroll company handle the tax aspect for you. They need to withhold taxes and pay taxes.  If they want to claim the childcare credit, you can obtain a TIN (tax identification number) from the IRS. That way they wouldn't have your SSN. If they want your SSN to do a background check, they can request it through Care, then they wouldn't have access to your SSN. You should find out what their plans are regarding the tax situation, because by law, you are considered a household employee (W-4/W-2), not an independent contractor (1099). I think you already know some of these facts, so I apologize for too much information. You and your employer could benefit from reading Publication 926, Household Employer's Tax Guide. Maybe Rachael can chime in with any info. I may have left out. Btw, you're right. You are not 1099. That would be consider tax evasion on their part. I hope this helps.

Hello! Happy new year! 
I am not sure if you live in another state when you said you are moving back home. But, depending on your location, some areas have high demands for nannies and you should definitely find out where because you don’t want to go to an area where the demand is scarce. You can sign up on so many different websites, have an outstanding profile (there are many posts regarding this if you can spend some times reading them) with 3 reviews by sending your links to your people to start with, add a background check plus premium or membership to boost you up as a beginner. But, keep in mind that the competition is harsh. There are other highly qualified applicants with Masters and P.H.D degrees. Being a nanny is not an easy job and it’s totally different from babysitting and most nannies make less on an hourly rate than sitters. If that is what you truly one, you can start babysitting varying from short hours (3hrs) to long ones (12hrs) in a day with different families from here and there until you are fully confident to switch to nannying. Your rate should always based on your location, experiences, education, certifications, number of kids and what the job entails. Keep in mind to not mix childcare with pet care and housekeeping because these 3 are separated jobs and mostly you will be low balled if you agree to them. If you want to drive kids to activities, charge the parents the irs rate of 58 cents per mileage to cover wears, tears and gas for your care no matter what! Nannies need to file for taxes, and the parents need to sign you up for a w4 and then give you a W2 at the end of January. You can find out more by checking out Homepay which is a method for taking care of your payroll and care has one on their profile if you go to your account and settings you will see it under more. Also get a contract about parents being respectful of your time, paid on time, paid vacation or holidays or sick days...Definitely do a lot of research before choosing which career path you what to pursue or if you want to do both. It’s your call and nobody else’s. It doesn’t matter whether your parents or friends agree to it or not. This is your own life and you have to make the best decision for yourself. Keep in mind that you will always have some roadblocks no matter whatever career you will choose. Unfortunately it’s a part of growing up as an adult. Life is only for the strong and if it gets hard, you need to still get it together and pull yourself from it instead of being in denials or giving up or switching to something else or trying to get married as if it will make things better. At some points you need to stop ✋🏾 and face your own reality, Good luck and happy new year!

Hi Joe, my name is Sam and I am a caregiver living in Ann Arbor, MI. I have some tips, pointers, tricks of the trade, etc. on being given further consideration for childcare positions.  I was in the same boat as you when I first started back in 2012 and as Christine said, there’s a certain prejudice on parents being uncomfortable with male caregivers but conversely, there are families that have a stronger preference for a male role model for a number of reasons like two mom families, single moms, child(ren) specifically asking for “boy babysitters,” and others.

There’s no telling how many applications you’ll submit before you’re given further consideration and finding the right fit; I lost count on the number of unsuccessful attempts before finding my first gig. Starting fresh is going to be very challenging but with persistence, you will prevail.  I’m living proof that male caregivers can succeed in an otherwise competitive industry.

Steps you can take to improve the odds on being given further consideration are as follows:

1. Clean up your profile —your care.com account/profile is a business profile advertising a service so make it appear like one as you highlight skills, experience, certifications (if any), education (if applicable), and miscellaneous relevant details.  Check for proper spelling, grammar, and overall presentation/flow; parents want a positive role model for their child(ren) that is a well spoken, reliable, and a good influence that conforms to high professional standard.

2. Strong First Impression—Just like your profile, your letter of application is going to be the first impression you make to prospective new family so make an effort to sell yourself and stand out above the competition as you highlight your skills and experience, acknowledge what the family is seeking (desired qualities and associated responsibilities, days and times needed, etc.), and a strong communicator. As before, double check proper spelling, grammar and overall flow presentation.

3. Resume —Having a resume shows you are serious about services you have to offer.  One little trick I found very helpful is creating a resume as a pdf/word doc on google docs, and including the link in my letter of application.  

4. Background Check —You say you have a clean background and MVR record; is it available on your care.com profile?  If not, I would recommend exploring possibility as it is a big scale tipper in your favor.  

5. References/Reviews —This is another major scale tipper.  For any families you worked for in the past (friends, family, neighbors, etc.), having solid references will make a difference.  Maybe some of them would be willing to write a review on your profile and improve your odds even further.  When I got my first job with a family, I had no reviews on my profile; the only things I had going for me were references they could contact, making a strong first impression in my letter of application and a professionally worded profile.  As I got to work with more families and accumulate reviews, it was considerably easier to be given further consideration for variety of positions in different capacities (part-time, full time, ad-hoc, alternate back-up, live in, etc.).  

Additional details to evaluate under advisement is the job postings open in your area: it’s pretty easy to distinguish families that are serious about committing to a service vs. families that aren’t 100% certain based on details displayed. If you see words like:
“Able to handle pickups/drop offs,”
“Our family loves playing games/sports so we hope you do too!”
“ Comfortable with pets” and many generic sounding sentences, don’t waste your time because those families checked off boxes and had a robot generated sentence with no substance because they don’t really know what they’re looking for.  Instead, look at postings with specific details on desired qualities of ideal caregiver, days and times needed, responsibilities, and overall a structured/official looking flow.  Limit your applications to families that have a picture AND clearly outlined needs; the rest aren’t worth the time of day.

Male caregivers may be the minority but that doesn’t make you any less important.  I used to volunteer at a shelter for survivors and their children of domestic violence as a playroom supervisor and my fellow male colleagues did an amazing job interacting with the kids so don’t let the biases/prejudices get to you.

If you have further questions and wish to discuss further, leave a response in the comments and I’ll respond as promptly as possible during breaks in workflow.

Cheers!

I made this post to highlight few things that you can try to improve if you are still trying to look for jobs. I am tired of hearing some people saying they can’t find a job, it’s a scam, how long will it take to be hired, is the premium worth it .....

    1) Your ability to find a job will depend on your LOCATION, EDUCATION, CERTIFICATIONS, EXPERIENCES... what the job entails, the number of kids, your rate.....
  2) PROFILE: the way you present yourself, should speak more about your qualifications. The app doesn’t have all of the features, so your best bet it to use the website on the “desktop site” to finish of what you started. Your biography should stand out and talk about what I mentioned on 1). Add a professional picture, a 20s video too. Parents also love to know what else you are currently doing beside being a caregiver and the activities you are willing to do/bring in.
  3) REVIEWS help a lot even if it’s 1 or 2. You can share your profile link to someone you worked with (even outside of care) to help you started.
  4) PREMIUM: A premium member ($20/mo or $50/6mo) will provide you with morning emails to go apply for jobs ahead of those that don’t have if, so you can be among the top applicants. It comes with a FREE motor vehicle record check. Having a background check ($33) done is separate from the premium perks. Also, you get to reply to parents back and forth and if you add a debit card on file, 3 reviews & all of those can boost you up to a CAREPRO status to increase your chances. As long as you are a premium member, parent can send you an automated message by declining you as a candidate and you can renew both of your background checks at anytime for free.
  5) CALENDAR: this is something that many people forget. Always add your availabilities to your calendar. It’s based on a 4 weeks timeframe. You can go back to it each Sunday to add more availability as the weeks go by.
 6) RESPONSE: to get a respond from a parent, you may wanna apply to many jobs even if it’s 50 days per day. Keep in mind that parents are not obliged to respond to anyone at all and you are competing with many qualified applicants as well and they cannot always get back to all 50+ persons. They might even forget to close the job or decline your offer, but you need to keep on applying.
7)  FAMILIES: when a family reach out to you, always welcome them first, then go back to the applications above to refresh your memory (sometimes they edit the jobs but you won’t get any alerts about it). Ask them about the days, hours (start and end time), mention your rate (stick to it and never go below your worth or at least the minimum hourly wage of your state. No flat rate!), the irs rate of 57.5 cents per mileage of driving their kids around on your own car is a must to cover gas, wears and tears, what the job entails, & talk about your expectations. If it sounds ok, then schedule a phone interview first before meeting up in person. This will save you a lot of times, efforts and bad reviews.
8) COMMUTE: Always think about how you will get to your job. Is it worth it driving/public transportation for 2hours to get to 2hours shift where you will be making less than $50 in total or spend more on your round trip than what you will be earning? Traffic can be jammed, road blocked, snow days...
9) FIRST DAY: when you have been fully hired, please before you go there, make sure you have had done some trials to see if it will be a good fit or not, signed a contract (guarantee hours, paid on time, cancelation fees...). I think you can get a sample on google but Racheal mentioned there nannnycounsel.com has a great one. They must enrolled you with Homepay on care of their accountant, so that you can fill out your W4 and get a W2 at the end of the year. DO NOT WORK under the table.
10) LEAVING: when things are not working out anymore, I am a big fun of communication and that is where you have to start talking and not wait until things get out of control. Are you being underpaid? Disrespected? Overworked than agreed on? Deserve a rate? New contract? .... SPEAK UP In person or/and send a group message as a reminder for x,y &Z. If none of that work, you may wanna quit or give a 2 weeks notice depending on your circumstances.

Finally, it takes times, efforts and some small investments to land a job. Use your time to fully explore each website (app doesn’t show much) that you are on. Read about the facts, check out previous topics discussed on this platform, look around and learn for yourself. Be patient, optimistic and you will be fine. There is no instant job anywhere in this world. You gotta work for it to get it! Hopefully, I didn’t strike a nerves on anyone. Thank you so much for your time! 😊

P.S: We do have a Facebook group “ All4One Caregivers” in case you want to meet some caregivers in your areas to connect with ... Feel free to join us!

- Ask past employers, family, and friends to post reviews for you. Believe it or not, the reviews do help. 
- Apply to as many jobs as you can. Be patient. Sometimes the families sort through several applications, so it may take hours, days, or weeks to sort through them and decide which caregivers the will speak to and interview.

Hey!

As well as being a long time member, I've helped several families find care and hire sitters through this site. 

-Get the background check. It shows parents that you're serious about looking for care. 

-Try to use proper grammar and punctuation on your profile. There are some fabulous sitters on here who don't speak English as their primary language, but having someone maybe proofread would be helpful, if possible. 

-READ the job posts. Some sitters will apply to anything and everything, whether the job is 30+ miles away, not actually available for the days and/or time frames needed, they don't have a vehicle and driving is part of the job, etc.

-Don't copy and paste the summary on your profile to job posts. It looks lazy and insincere. 

-Don't mention anything about needing/wanting to earn money in your profile or messages sent to parents. It looks desperate. 

Hope this helps and good luck!

I’m sorry but every time I see a post along these lines, it amazes.....astounds.....even somewhat confuses me that those that are new seem to think that if they apply for 20, 30, even 50 jobs......that they will get massive responses. This site does NOT guarantee anyone a job. They are the middle man, the intermediary, the go between.....helping those seeking childcare connect with those who are looking for a childcare position and visa versa. If you are young and have little to no experience, it’s going to be very difficult to find a job. If you are a college student who can only work certain days & certain hours and that changes with each semester, it’s going to be difficult to find a position. Yes, I applaud you for your hard work & dedication in getting your education, but the majority of families are looking for someone full time or part time with set days & hours. 

If I’ve said it once, I’ve said it a hundred times.....you can apply to one hundred jobs and beyond that with the exception of a follow up message (thanking the family from accepting your application and that you look forward to hearing from them soon) there is absolutely nothing you can do. A family listing a job may get dozens of responses. They may or may not read all of them. They may skim through and pick just a few. If you are not among the chosen few, do not expect any kind of acknowledgement. In over 2.5 years and the dozens of applicants that I have put out, I have received TWO responses that basically said “thank you for your application, but we have decided to go in a different direction”. One of you must have premium in order for messages to go back & forth. I see so many caregivers say “I’m no paying for premium. I’m not paying for a background check. Those are the responsibility of the employer,” Did you ever stop to think the potential employers are waiting for applications thinking “It’s not my responsibility to get premium or pay for a background check, if they want a job badly enough they will pay for it.”  Did anyone ever think of that? And if they want a background background check on every person that they interview, even four interviews add up to over $100. If one is hired, $75 down the drain. If no one is hired $100 gone for nothing. No one seems to want to look at both sides of the coin....job seekers OR potential employers. 

You can have what you believe to be the best references, experience and application.....and you can stand on your head and sing Mary had a Little Lamb until pigs fly, but there is absolutely nothing that you can do to make anyone respond to your application, in any way-shape-or form.

Hi Emma, 
Premium membership- Not necessary, but you will only be able to communicate with the families who have purchased the premium membership. Either you or the family has to purchase the membership in order to communicate. You will also remain higher in the search results and will be notified of jobs in your area. I didn't purchase the membership on Care until I was on here for about two years. I believe it helped me, along with other things. If you're trying to save your money, then continue to search for jobs and hope that the families you apply to have the premium membership. 
Background checks- In my opinion, they're not necessary, unless a family requests one. If a family interviews you and you both agree that you want to move forward with the hiring process, they will most likely ask about a background check. At that time you can explain to them that you don't currently have one on file, but you're willing to get one at their request and at their expense. I have never purchased a background check. My current family purchased it. It's valid for 6 months. 
Reviews- You can ask past employers, family, and friends to post reviews for you. The reviews can help the families get an idea of who you are, how you work with children, your work ethic, etc. I got my current job because the mother saw my profile and reviews, so she reached out to me because of what she read. I never applied for the position. She reached out to me, we met, I fell in love with the baby, and the rest is history...
Good luck to you, Emma.

Scams come in all shapes and sizes on here just as much as anywhere else in the world. A really common one is someone saying they’re moving from another state who wants you to buy stuff ahead of time and they are sending you a check to cash and pay for the stuff and you can keep some of the money. This check will be bogus and you will be held liable by your bank. Also if they say hurry because their accounts being closed that is a big red flag that screams SCAM!!! Accounts are only closed if people voluntarily close them OR if Care.com recognizes them as a scam. 

A good rule of thumb is: if it sounds to good to be true, it probably is.  Be alert and try to “read between the lines” to changes in the info they’re giving you or really bad spelling and grammar. Sometimes it’s someone who’s first language isn’t English, but if they’re living and working at a job good enough to enable them to have a Nanny, their English is usually pretty good. 

Make ALL initial communication through the Care.com site until you feel confident this is a “real” person, offering a pay scale, working conditions, and hours that will be satisfactory to you. Do NOT give them any personal info until you’ve at least reached this point. Then it’s best to have them put in for a Carechat with you.  You do not have to give access to your background check to this point either.
